Horace cannot perhaps from every point of view be described as a. great artist; and yet his poems have perhaps found more favour with posterity than the work of any of his contemporaries. No Roman poet has been so frequently quoted in English books or in every-day conversation. While not distinguished for any especial originality of thought his poems have always been found to ponem a certain irresistible chami, and his good sense, his broad humanity, his perfect urbanity cannot fail to appeel to his readers.
